nytimes_articles.headline: The Pope On Scandal: Excerpts
nytimes_articles.abstract: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's June 11 letter to the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States, as supplied by the United States Catholic Conference. The emphasis is in the original.   Venerable and Dear Brother Bishops of the United States:

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan's Governing Party Splinters Again as 10 Legislators Leave
nytimes_articles.abstract: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party continued to splinter today, as a group of 10 young legislators broke off to form yet another new party that further reduces the chances that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's Government will be able to hold onto power.   The defection would in ordinary times pose little threat to the Liberal Democrats. But another 35 to 40 party members, who led the rebellion that forced a no-confidence vote against Mr. Miyazawa through Parliament on Friday, is expected to announce later this week that it is also forming a rival party. Those defections mean that the Liberal Democrats have lost their majority in the powerful lower house of Parliament, and to retain power would have to defeat the splinter groups in next month's election.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editors' Note
nytimes_articles.abstract: A brief article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on June 8 about the Worthen Banking Corporation of Little Rock, Ark., reported that the company made $59.5 million in loans to its principal shareholders, officers and directors in 1992. The article also noted in the first sentence that Worthen was under investigation by the Federal Reserve for possible violations of banking law.    In fairness, the article should not have linked the investigation to the loans.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: Assaults on Italy : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA - [From our New York edition:] Waves of American and British bombers, striking from bases in North Africa and the Middle East, rocked the Italian mainland yesterday [June 22] with shattering assaults on the port of Napl

nytimes_articles.headline: Washington at Work; Long-Running Culture War Opens New Front: an Arts Nomination
nytimes_articles.abstract: It rarely rises to the prominence of the great struggles over taxes or abortion, but the culture war continues along the border of academia and politics. It is bitter, long-running and intense, and Sheldon Hackney has found himself in the thick of it.   Mr. Hackney, the president of the University of Pennsylvania, was nominated by President Clinton last week to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. On paper, his confirmation would seem routine, even preordained: A career marked by steady advancement in higher education; important and vocal friends from Mike Wallace, the journalist, to C. Vann Woodward, the historian; and intriguing Southern roots. His in-laws, Virginia and Clifford Durr, were renowned Alabama liberals who helped bail out Rosa Parks. His wife, Lucy Durr Hackney, is a children's advocate and a friend of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

nytimes_articles.headline: Betty Carter and Gerry Mulligan in a Retrospective Mood
nytimes_articles.abstract: The jazz world has recently lost so many musical giants that the JVC Jazz Festival's opening-night concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday had an inevitably elegiac flavor. After a jocular Bill Cosby introduced the concert's two stars, Betty Carter and Gerry Mulligan, the mood quickly turned soberly retrospective.    Ms. Carter opened her set with a probing rendition of "You're Mine, You," an eerie proclamation of sexual possessiveness offered in tribute to Sarah Vaughan, who once recorded it. Mr. Mulligan and his group played individual compositions in memory of Miles Davis, Dizzy Gillespie, Stan Getz and Zoot Sims. "It's kind of hard to realize we did the first summer festival at Newport 40 years ago," Mr. Mulligan, who is 66, observed wistfully near the end of his set. "I was the new kid on the block."

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinosaurs' Doom Tied To Several Impacts
nytimes_articles.abstract: A NEW report suggests that the celestial body that may have wiped out dinosaurs 65 million years ago was not a single mass but a swarm of separate objects. The suggestion comes even as some 20 large cometary fragments rush through space toward a predicted collision with Jupiter next year, seeming to give the new report a cosmic boost.   The idea that a doomsday rock did in the dinosaurs was first proposed in 1980 by Dr. Walter Alvarez, a geologist at the University of California at Berkeley. He and his colleagues had found unusually large amounts of the rare metal iridium in sediments laid down about the time the dinosaurs died out, at the end of the Cretaceous period. They proposed that the iridium came from a cosmic catastrophe.

nytimes_articles.headline: New York City Census Profile Shows Stark Changes in Decade
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even as real income rose in all but three of New York's neighborhoods in the 1980's, one of the city's poorest places -- Hunts Point in the Bronx -- grew poorer by 30 percent. On Staten Island, the most suburban borough, the number of foreign-born people increased four times faster than in the city as a whole. And the number of New Yorkers with college degrees increased more than 44 percent.    Fleshing out a stark profile, a new portrait of New York City drawn from the 1990 census reveals broad demographic changes along with striking contrasts in neighborhoods that have reinvented themselves to accommodate newcomers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cradle of Russian Revolution a Hotbed of Disgust
nytimes_articles.abstract: On any given day, the various strands of St. Petersburg's myriad Communist, nationalist, even fascist movements come together by the wooden fence that surrounds an old merchants' emporium, Gostini Dvor, on Nevsky Prospekt in the heart of the old city.   There, young nationalists and aging Communists mingle peacefully beneath wall art that features handwritten quotes from Lenin or more current idols of the ultra-patriots, behind tables stacked with copies of Pravda, the old Communist Party daily, or newer publications like Russian Order, Russian Cause, To the Ax and Nationalist, each trying to outdo the others in proving that this or that member of President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government is Jewish, a paid agent of the C.I.A., or both.

nytimes_articles.headline: Defense in Bombing Challenges Evidence
nytimes_articles.abstract: A lawyer for one of the prime suspects in the World Trade Center bombing contends in court papers that the Federal Bureau of Investigation relied on an agent's "deliberately or recklessly false" sworn statement to search a storage locker where explosive chemicals were found.   Providing a first look at some of the main defense strategies in the case, the lawyer, Robert E. Precht, argued that the F.B.I. ignored information that electromagmetic devices, wiring, manuals and tools seized from a Jersey City apartment of Mohammed A. Salameh had actually been claimed as teaching materials by an electrical engineering professor.

nytimes_articles.headline: White Sox Sign Former Quarterback
nytimes_articles.abstract: A former University of Washington quarterback, BILLY JOE HOBERT, drafted by teams in two professional sports, signed yesterday with the Chicago White Sox.   Hobert, an outfielder, was picked by the White Sox in the 16th round of this month's draft. He is expected to soon join Chicago's team in Sarasota in the Gulf Coast League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart grouping in Business Day yesterday with an article about Apple Computer Inc. included an erroneous label for two pie charts. The charts, showing market share percentages for personal computer sales by Apple, Compaq Computer and International Business Machines, were for only one month apiece -- April 1992 and April 1993 -- and not the first four months of each year.

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Bombs Kill 7 in Madrid; Basques Are Suspected
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two car bombs exploded in downtown Madrid this morning, killing 7 people and wounding more than 20, the authorities said.   Although no one claimed responsibility, the authorities suspect the Basque terrorist organization E.T.A., which has killed more than 750 people in its 25-year campaign for independence for three northern provinces.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. GIVES MEXICO ABDUCTION PLEDGE
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration has promised Mexico that it will not engage in any cross-border kidnapping of Mexican citizens while an agreement between the two countries banning the practice is being negotiated, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today.    At a news conference with Fernando Solana Morales, Mexico's Secretary of Foreign Relations, Mr. Christopher said the two countries had begun negotiations on the issue.

nytimes_articles.headline: China Breaks Ground for World's Largest Dam
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE bulldozers are scooping out the yellow earth along the Yangtze River in preparation for the world's largest hydroelectric project, a dam that will create a lake 350 miles long, fuel China's industrial revolution and save millions of people from the constant threat of flooding.   Or perhaps the project will simply create the world's most colossal mud pie.

nytimes_articles.headline: Casinos' Unkept Promise Turns 15; Atlantic City Wants to Stop Being Gambling's Bad Example
nytimes_articles.abstract: With casinos spreading across the country like stacks of chips at a hot roulette table, two things are clear as this aging resort celebrates the 15th anniversary of legal gambling here.   First, Atlantic City has demonstrated the money to be made in casinos and other games of chance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Didn't Anyone Watch the Mets?
nytimes_articles.abstract: NBC is assured of breaking the ratings record for the National Basketball Association finals with its 21.8 overnight rating and 40 share for Sunday's Game 6 of the Bulls-Suns series. An overnight rating is drawn from 29 markets equaling 50.7 percent of the nation's television households.   Heading into Sunday, the average national rating for the first five games of the finals was 17.5/32. Thus, even if the Game 6 rating falls modestly, NBC is certain to beat the finals record of 15.9/32 set in 1987, when the Lakers beat the Celtics.

nytimes_articles.headline: Surgery for Blackman, Rivers
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two Knick guards underwent surgery last week, Rolando Blackman on Saturday for a herniated disk in his lower back and Doc Rivers a day earlier for torn ligaments in his right hand. The Knicks are hoping Blackman will be ready when training camp opens in October and expect Rivers to be fit.   Blackman's surgery was more serious, particularly for a player 34 years old. He played the entire season with a herniated disk and had his worst season, averaging 9.7 points during the regular season, and just 4.2 points during the playoffs. But Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team physician, said there was reason to be optimistic that Blackman would return to form next season.

nytimes_articles.headline: Housing Agency Says Federal Aid Is Not at Risk
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City Housing Authority officials yesterday adamantly denied a report charging that more than a billion dollars in Federal aid was at risk because the agency's spending plan was behind schedule.   A report in yesterday's issue of New York Newsday said that within the last decade the amount of unspent capital funds available to the city had risen beyond $1.1 billion. The Newsday report cited as its source a Department of Housing and Urban Development performance review sent to Sally Hernandez-Pinero, chairwoman of the Housing Authority, last month.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan: How Clean a Break?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Politicians continue to defect from Japan's Liberal Democratic Party in the wake of last Friday's no-confidence vote in Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. Some of these are honest reformers, outraged at the Liberal Democrats' failure to meet the public demand for a cleaner system. Others are opportunists, betting on political realignment as the quickest ticket to the rewards of high office.    It's high drama -- the fracturing of a system of one-party rule that delivered remarkable economic growth and endured for almost 40 years. But beneath the choreographed rituals of Japanese party politics lie even more dramatic changes in public opinion. A new generation of urban Japanese, raised in affluence, is now turning against big-money politics while it seeks a better balance between producer and consumer interests in Japanese life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Electrical Emissions: Dangerous Or Not?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ELECTROMAGNETIC fields, linked for more than a decade, however tenuously, with cancer in children, have become the stuff of nightmares. Entrepreneurs have been doing a brisk business selling devices to measure EMF's, as they are known, in the home or office. And utility companies are quietly spending $1 billion a year nationwide to reduce exposures from their power lines and facilities, while preparing to face a barrage of lawsuits holding them responsible for childhood cancers.

But in a recent lawsuit in San Diego, the first such case to go to trial, a jury rejected a couple's claim that their 5-year-old daughter's rare form of kidney cancer had been caused by the tangle of power lines hanging ominously above their home. The San Diego case raised the question of just how strong the scientific evidence is linking electromagnetic fields and cancer, and whether the public's anxiety is valid.

nytimes_articles.headline: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Decide if Ash Is a Hazardous Waste
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a case that could help determine the economics of municipal waste disposal, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the ash left from the burning of municipal solid waste must be treated as hazardous waste, requiring special treatment that could increase the cost of disposal by as much as 10 times.   The issue has been one of the more disputed aspects of Federal environmental policy in recent years. It has split the lower Federal courts and has produced an agonizing series of policy changes within the Environmental Protection Agency, which issued a policy statement last fall stating that the ash should be exempted from hazardous waste regulation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gooden Sits, Young Starts
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dwight Gooden, after complaining of stiffness in his right shoulder, will be held out of his scheduled start against the Montreal Expos tonight at Shea Stadium. He will be replaced by Anthony Young, which will give that right-hander a head start on what might be history as he attempts to end his streak of 22 straight decisions without a victory.   Gooden, who was rocked for six runs in three innings last Thursday night in Pittsburgh, was examined by Dr. David Dines yesterday. The discomfort was officially termed minor, a designation that has come to mean increasingly little over the years with the Mets. Gooden will be examined again today.

nytimes_articles.headline: Albany, Not City Hall, Holds Purse Strings for Transit Upgrade
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Find Money for the M.T.A." (editorial, June 12) faults the New York City administration for not bearing its share of the cost of improvements on subways and buses.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reining In School Custodians
nytimes_articles.abstract: For too long, New York City school custodians have wielded power and privilege far out of proportion to their numbers -- and beyond the scope of any sensible labor-management pact. Now the State Assembly has tried to cut them down to size. The Senate needs to follow suit.    Custodians function as both city employees and independent contractors. Each of the 900 custodians administers an annual allowance, based on the size of the school, for supplies, equipment and salaries for the custodial staff.

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Jersey Symphony  Carnegie Hall    A positive side to America's musical establishment is the relative absence of chauvinism in its ranks. While the hiring of an American soprano at the English National Opera continues to provoke patriotic wrath from high musical places in Britain, the Leonard Bernstein American Conductors Program seemed happy to put two young foreign-born conductors in front of the New Jersey Symphony on Thursday night. Fabio Mechetti from Brazil conducted "Medea's Meditation and Dance of Vengeance," by Barber, and excerpts from Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet." Alasdair Neale, a transplanted Briton, led the Ravel "Rapsodie Espagnole" and "Till Eulenspiegel's Merry Pranks," by Richard Strauss.

nytimes_articles.headline: French-Fry War: Israel vs. McDonald's
nytimes_articles.abstract: Here in Israel's potato-growing country, making his way among machines that cleaned, sliced, packaged and froze the new crop, Shai Hermesh talked with some bitterness about the enemy.   He did not mean destructive insects, or capricious weather, or even Palestinian terrorists from the Gaza Strip, a few miles west.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suns Begin Looking For the Missing Piece
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley's summer vacation began with -- what else? -- a television commercial. Literally 100 minutes after the Chicago Bulls had wiped their hands of the Phoenix Suns on Sunday night, Barkley parked himself in front of a rolling camera and said, "I'm still going to Disney World."   Then this morning, Jerry Colangelo's summer vacation began with -- what else? -- a scan of the free-agent list. Perhaps only a stubborn rebounder or defender away from a National Basketball Association title, Colangelo, the Suns' chief executive officer, has all but guaranteed one key acquisition. The Nets' Chris Dudley, an unrestricted free agent and a wall-banger at forward and center, seems to be a prime candidate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Auerbach on Mend From Heart Surgery
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Boston Celtics' president, RED AUERBACH, was progressing satisfactorily at Massachusetts General Hospital yesterday, three days after undergoing heart bypass surgery.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: Déjeuner for Zola : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - M. Emile Zola was entertained at a déjeuner in the Bois de Boulogne yesterday [June 21] by his publisher, literary admirers and friends. M. Charpentier rose at dessert and spoke, recalling the hardships M. Zola had had to suffer at the commen

nytimes_articles.headline: Scientists Decipher Mysterious Process Of Signaling in Cells
nytimes_articles.abstract: A PATIENT with kidney failure has just received a transplant. Within seconds sentinel cells of the immune system approach it, touching it to determine if it is friend or foe. If these white blood cells determine that the kidney is a foreign body, a signal passes through them, telling them to grow and divide and to secrete a hormone to recruit other cells to the area. Thus is started an attack that if not defused, will culminate in the body's rejection of the new organ.   So how does it happen? How can a chemical contact on the outside of a cell be translated into a signal to DNA, the genetic material deep inside the cell, to divide and make new hormones?

nytimes_articles.headline: The Politics of Meaning : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: These articles bring out the privileged childhood and elitist education of the former Hillary Rodham. It is shocking to read her revelations of her self-ordained enlightenment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Service for Walter Wood
nytimes_articles.abstract: A memorial service for Walter A. Wood, explorer and geographer, will be held at 11 A.M. on Thursday at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st Street. Dr. Wood, past president of the American Geographical Society and the Explorers Club, died on May 18 at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 85.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; Clinton, Iraq And Iran
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the winter and spring of 1993, the Clinton Administration quietly worked out an important new policy toward the two countries that could involve the United States again in Mideastern war.    Since Europe was busy boxing Mr. Clinton's ears about not taking over its job on Bosnia, and the American press and public were out getting a haircut, the Administration managed to squeeze in some useful thinking on Iran and Iraq without being belabored for it.

nytimes_articles.abstract: EMPIRE SAYS IT DID NOT VERIFY ALL CLAIMS   Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has routinely paid claims from doctors, hospitals and pharmacies without any attempt to determine whether the claims had already been paid or were fraudulent, company officials acknowledged. nytimes_articles.headline: Bonilla Rediscovers Sweet Swing Amid Pain of a Lost Season
nytimes_articles.abstract: Evidently, for the Mets to win a game, Bobby Bonilla must make it his own. Bonilla is turning on everything at the plate. Almost always these days, it is with purpose. Absolutely always, it is with power.   Bonilla, who can drive in runs even when he swings off balance, found his sweetest rhythm in the fifth inning last night at Shea Stadium. The switch-hitter's two-run homer into the loge seats in left lifted the Mets to an 8-3 victory over the Montreal Expos. The homer, Bonilla's 18th of the season, accounted for his third and fourth runs batted in on the night and ended the club's losing streak at six.

nytimes_articles.headline: HIGH COURT BACKS POLICY OF HALTING HAITIAN REFUGEES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court today upheld the Bush and Clinton Administrations' policy of intercepting fleeing Haitians at sea and returning them to Haiti without asylum hearings.   The 8-to-1 decision, written by Justice John Paul Stevens with a dissent by Justice Harry A. Blackmun, concluded that the policy was permitted under Federal immigration law and an international treaty to which the United States is a party.

nytimes_articles.headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gilbert Shelton, cartoonist, is reading Alistair Horne's "The Fall of Paris: The Siege and the Co."It's a fascinating bit of neglected history. The bourgeoisie killed something like 10 times the number of people the revolutionaries killed a c

nytimes_articles.headline: Isolation and Internal Unrest Trouble Iran
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Interior Minister Abdollah Nouri, seated in an ornate room with lacy curtains and a panoramic view of Teheran, was asked a few days ago about the killings of Iranian dissidents abroad, he condemned the dead rather than the living.   "How many terrorist activities and explosions inside Iran have these people confessed to?" the Minister asked, referring to such opposition leaders as Mohammed Hussein Nagdi, a former Ambassador to Italy, who was gunned down in Rome.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Politics of Meaning : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: While I am supportive of Mrs. Clinton seeking to redefine the role of first lady, her statements carry a fuzzy-headedness that is inconsistent with the power she wields. Indeed, she seems to contradict herself on her aims, enthusiastically responding, &q

nytimes_articles.headline: Join New Talks, Europeans Urge Bosnia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rejecting new appeals from President Clinton and the Bosnian Government for a lifting of the international arms embargo on its forces, European Community governments today urged Bosnia's Muslim President, Alija Izetbegovic, to join new peace negotiations with Serbia and Croatia in Geneva this week.   The European governments insisted that they remained committed to preservation of a single state in Bosnia and Herzegovina and that they would not press the Bosnian Muslims into accepting a peace settlement of which they disapproved. But Mr. Izetbegovic was left in little doubt that the community has abandoned the so-called Vance-Owen peace plan and now considers the Serbian-Croatian plan that calls for the partition of Bosnia as the focus of future negotiations.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: Flu at the Front : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: BRITISH FRONT - The lull on the whole British front is outlasting all expectations, including those of the Germans. A few days ago it was thought that the enemy would start a very powerful offensive. Everything was ready. The artillery preparation seemed

nytimes_articles.headline: Police Drama Under Fire for Sex and Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: Though it will not be broadcast until September, a new ABC television series, "N.Y.P.D. Blue," has become the target of the latest campaign by a Mississippi minister to compel the broadcast networks to censor material he finds offensive.   As has been the case before, the Rev. Donald Wildmon of Tupelo, Miss., is campaigning against material he has not seen. But Steven Bochco, the creator and executive producer of "N.Y.P.D. Blue," all but gave notice that his latest series would raise hackles when he publicly predicted it would be the first "R rated" show on network television.

nytimes_articles.headline: I.O.C. Plans Arbitration Procedures for Athletes
nytimes_articles.abstract: The International Olympic Committee moved closer yesterday to setting up an arbitration system to keep disgruntled athletes from filing lawsuits and took the first steps toward getting federations to standardize penalties on athletes who use banned substances.   In a joint meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, the I.O.C. executive board and the council of the Association of Summer Olympic International Federations recommended uniform penalties and rules governing use of performance-enhancing drugs. Federations would risk being kicked out of Olympic competition unless they agreed to comply -- assuming they are able to agree on such things as testing procedures and penalties in the first place.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Civilization Knot : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: In his classification of civilizations around the world, Mr. Huntington separates "Japanese civilization" from its "Western" and "Confucian" counterparts. This was the first time that I, a Japanese national, have ever heard

nytimes_articles.headline: Ftorek's Name Is Scratched In Devils' Coaching Derby
nytimes_articles.abstract: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 21    Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils, promised today that the team would name its new head coach sometime next week, following Saturday's amateur draft. It will not be Robbie Ftorek, who was considered the front-runner for the job vacated by the departure of Herb Brooks three weeks ago.   Ftorek will remain coach of the Devils' top affiliate at Albany because Lamoriello believes he is the ideal person to develop the young players in the Devils' system.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was well known that Lee Hazen, who died early last year, was a superb card player. But there is some evidence that his wife, Sylvia, who died early this month, was also a star, although she did not take part in tournaments. She was the prototype of a character named Sylvia who appeared in many of the syndicated columns of the late B. J. Becker, and she always emerged as the heroine.   Luck often played a part, but on the diagramed deal, sitting West, she was operating on a sound principle: If the opponent obviously wants you to do something, do something else.

nytimes_articles.headline: Best and Worst of Times In Tale of 2 Crazy Eddies
nytimes_articles.abstract: DAVID M. LANE felt compelled to come to Room 5A in the Federal District Courthouse here for the trial of Eddie Antar, and for a glimpse into the lost world of Crazy Eddie Inc.   "I was drawn to come and lay eyes on him again," Mr. Lane said.   Mr. Antar, as his lawyers seem doomed to repeat forever, is not Crazy Eddie. That was a corporation, an idea, a persona that blasted its way under the skin of millions of residents of the New York region in the 1970's and 1980's through the arm-waving, eye-bulging television antics of the pitchman Jerry Carroll. The consumer electronics chain, 42 stores at its peak, all clustered in and around New York City, crashed into bankruptcy in 1987, and finally liquidation in 1990.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pictures Are Better on Radio
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The mind's eye is a powerful projector. What we can imagine is usually scarier, funnier, more real and more vivid than the explicit images of video. Some of the wiser film directors have taken this lesson to heart: In horror movies, it is a mistake to show the monster before the end of the film. Left to the imagination, our minds create demons far scarier than any film maker's image. And ask any baseball fan about the crack of the bat and the lilt of an announcer's voice coming over the airwaves on a languid summer afternoon. The pictures are better on radio.

The profits are better on radio as well, at least at some points on the dial, a fact confirmed the other day when the Infinity Broadcast Corporation paid $110 million for KRTH-FM in Los Angeles. It was the highest price ever paid for a single radio station, prompted by radio's ability to identify valuable demographic segments for advertisers (in this case, 25-to-44-year-olds who listen to oldies).

nytimes_articles.headline: Islanders Did Best in the Great Goalie Sweepstakes
nytimes_articles.abstract: By getting goalie Ron Hextall from Quebec before the pre-expansion trading deadline, the Islanders may have made the best acquisition in a flurry of trades leading up to this week's double draft.   But it is the Nordiques, for the third consecutive season, who command the most attention as the league gathers this week -- coincidentally, in the Nordiques' home town -- for several days of dealings.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Seen against the high standard Samuel P. Huntington has established in the study of international relations at Harvard, his recent contribution to your opinion pages entitled "Now Watch the Fault Lines Between Civilizations" (June 8) was a stra

nytimes_articles.headline: The Bulls Belong Past and Future
nytimes_articles.abstract: With three consecutive championships and a young nucleus capable of winning more titles, the Chicago Bulls are secure about their place in history.   Countering arguments that they do not measure up to some of the all-time great National Basketball Association teams, the Bulls feel their accomplishments speak for themselves. In an era of free agency and multimillion-dollar contracts, the Bulls have remained hungry, determined and unified. When they were challenged this season -- by the Knicks, by the Phoenix Suns and by off-court distractions -- the Bulls responded by winning. The route to a third title was more difficult than Chicago expected, which made this year's playoff run more impressive -- and more satisfying.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Falsettos' to Close
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Falsettos," a musical by William Finn and James Lapine and directed by Mr. Lapine, is to close after the Sunday matinee at the Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The matinee on Sunday will be the 487th regular performance; it had 23 previews.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Thrill of a Superfast Deskpro
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE INTEL CORPORATION's new Pentium microprocessor has been employed primarily in the class of floor-standing personal computers called servers, which act as hubs for networks of lesser PC's. For those of us who do not have Novell networks installed in the den or in the spare bedroom that we have converted into a home office, some companies are setting aside a few of their precious Pentium chips for use in conventional desktop computers.   One of the first of these fire-breathing PC's, the Compaq Computer Corporation's Deskpro 5/60M, arrived in my office recently. It came with a 20-inch Compaq QVision monitor, and it was stuffed with more than half a gigabyte of hard disk storage, 16 megabytes of system memory and a CD-ROM drive, which I used to install the OS/2 version 2.1 operating system.

nytimes_articles.headline: Regional Party in Northern Italy And Ex-Communists Gain in Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: The insurgent Northern League tightened its hold in northern Italy today with the release of final results from nationwide mayoral elections that confirmed voters' rejection of the scandal-ridden parties that had led this country since World War II.   But the ex-Communist Democratic Party of the Left also benefited from the traditional parties' disgrace, seeing its fortunes and its standing as a national party rise after years of decline.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "There aren't many places in the world where you can find cheap labor, a skilled work force and a good location. We can take advantage of all that here." -- VOLKHARD KOHLER, an executive at a Czech automobile plant.  [ D6:1. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Help on Screen for Dad Or a Parent-in-Waiting
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN the contractions start coming five minutes apart, it is time to turn on the computer.   Actually, the program B.A.B.Y. (Birth and Baby Years) spans a much longer period, from before conception through birth and into the early months of infanthood. It covers medical and nutritional information; illustrated guides to ovulation, conception and birth itself, and even a list of possible names.

nytimes_articles.headline: Joe Louis Gets His 29¦ Worth
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States Postal Service today will offer its first homage to a professional boxer with a 29-cent stamp featuring Joe Louis.    The Postal Service and its predecessor, the Post Office Department, has issued 102 stamps and postal cards on sports themes since 1932. But the vast majority have been generic designs, including 67 just for the Olympics; only 14 notable sports figures have been honored.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's a Nanometer in Diameter, and Now It Can Be Made in Bulk
nytimes_articles.abstract: JAPANESE and American research teams have discovered two different ways to make bulk quantities of carbon "nanotubes," microscopic tubes with walls whose standard thickness is only a single atom.   The techniques may herald major advances in ultrastrong materials, microscopic electronic circuits and many other technologies. Since nanotubes can now be produced by the pound, these peculiar carbon structures will be available for the first time for experiments by legions of chemists, physicists, materials scientists and engineers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Greenville Journal; Where Moose Is Monarch of All Who Survey It
nytimes_articles.abstract: To get to Greenville (pop. 1,900), just follow Route 15 north, said the car rental agent at the airport in Bangor. Handing over the keys and a map, he warned, "Watch out for large animals." It was dusk. He meant moose.   Seventy-five miles down the road, in Monson, the cashier at Page's General Store said Greenville was 14 miles ahead. "Watch out for moose," she said. "They'll kill you if they come through your windshield."

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins and Giuliani Go to Legislature
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mayor David N. Dinkins and his Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, brought their mayoral campaigns to Albany today, shadowing each other through the State Capitol as they lobbied legislators to maintain existing rent regulations on New York City apartments.   Legislators, legislative aides and lobbyists said that Mr. Giuliani, by making his own trip here, was acknowledging that the issue could play badly for him if the State Senate, which is controlled by his party, insists on weakening protections for an estimated two million tenants.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSURERS MAY FACE GREATER SCRUTINY
nytimes_articles.abstract: To increase competition in the market for medical care, White House officials are recommending that the health-insurance industry be stripped of its longstanding immunity from Federal antitrust law.   The proposal reflects the concern of Administration officials and consumer advocates who fear that a handful of big insurance companies may soon dominate the industry, especially if Congress approves the plan Mr. Clinton is developing to overhaul the nation's health-care system.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Battle Between Cities May Scuttle Navy Base
nytimes_articles.abstract: With its tiny fleet of rusty shrimp boats, screeching sea gulls and wind-blown resort homes, this small community on the muddy tidal flats of the Texas coast seems an unlikely battlefield in the bureaucratic wars over shrinking dollars for the military.   But as a result of voting by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission beginning this week, the brand-new $440 million Naval Station Ingleside nearby may be ordered closed, victim of a sophisticated lobbying campaign in a tug-of-war whose stakes are thousands of jobs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Two Months At Home With Jordan
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT feels like we've been guests in Michael Jordan's house for two solid months. Watched him rise in the morning and go off to work. Looked in his closets and under his rugs. Shared his smile and made him scowl. Marveled at his highs and psychoanalyzed his lows.   We spent so much quality time with Jordan that he often seemed like he just wanted to be left alone. Three consecutive springs as host to the National Basketball Association playoffs might even make a reticent soul of Charles Barkley. One spring has Barkley contemplating, however whimsically, quitting the game.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Courage to Reform Rent Controls
nytimes_articles.abstract: With one bold move, the State Senate's majority leader can force a confrontation on New York City's destructive rent regulations. The leader, Ralph Marino, can couple a two-year extension of New York's rent laws with legislation gradually removing controls on luxury apartments. That would force Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin to let the laws expire or adopt luxury decontrol.   Mr. Marino supports luxury decontrol, as do some other Republican senators from New York City. But two key Senators -- Roy Goodman of Manhattan and Frank Padavan of Queens -- do not. Neither, disappointingly, does Rudolph Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor. Given that lineup, it will be difficult for Mr. Marino to take a stand. But it would be worth it to New York City.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kukoc Not Playing for Croats; Fans Riot 'Nicely' in Chicago
nytimes_articles.abstract: After meeting with Croatian officials this weekend, Toni Kukoc has decided not to play in the European Championships this week in Germany, his agent said Monday. .Kukoc, despite a difficult tonsillectomy recently in the United States, was under intense

nytimes_articles.headline: The Palace Coup That Failed
nytimes_articles.abstract: The battle for Guatemala has only just begun. Even as its citizens and democrats everywhere savor the stunning defeat of a tyrannical coup, the restoration of constitutional rule and the election of not merely a civilian President but one committed to human rights, we should not be naive about how fragile the victory is.   The dizzying power struggle that began May 25 will be decisive in shaping the course of Guatemalan politics for many years to come.

nytimes_articles.headline: A New Serve, but the Same Old Agassi
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wimbledon, that green-and-purple bastion of tradition, got under way today with nothing less than a travesty overhead: a dose of summer-solstice sunshine that refused to depart until 10 P.M. and wreaked no havoc with the opening-day schedule.   But decorum ruled under the royal eyes on Centre Court this afternoon when defending champion Andre Agassi successfully negotiated his first-round match in straight sets. Agassi's dicey drama with right wrist tendinitis had provoked speculation he might become the first defender to suffer a first-round falter since Charlie Pasarell dethroned Manuel Santana in 1967.

nytimes_articles.headline: McHale to Work for Wolves On, Off Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: Retired Boston Celtics star KEVIN McHALE will return to Minnesota to work with the Timberwolves and add commentary to game broadcasts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Jazz Festival; Making People Scream: Illinois Jacquet and Band
nytimes_articles.abstract: From his first hard-toned and heavy notes, rife with the blues and redolent of so much history, Illinois Jacquet had the audience. Leading his big band at Damrosch Park on Sunday afternoon as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, Mr. Jacquet opened his solo and the crowd, sun-baked and happy, let out a collective sigh.   For the rest of the concert, Mr. Jacquet (pronounced jah-KETT) had people going. His improvisations, completely assured rhythmically, made people scream. His blues playing, direct and raw, had them standing. And just the simple strength of his tone, coarse and authoritative, made everything he played seem declarative, as if he were preaching a sermon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Foreign Press Can Beat Japanese System
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Japan Opens Door Wider to the Foreign Press" (news article, June 11) reports that Japan's newspaper editors will allow foreign journalists to join the exclusive press clubs, which control access to Government briefings. This is welcome news.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dateline, Toronto: A Big Moment for Key, A Big Test for Yanks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The image that most baseball fans have of Jimmy Key occurred last October when he ambled off the mound at the Skydome in Toronto, raised his cap to the fans and looked as if he might cry. Key had just pitched wondrously against Atlanta in Game 4 of the World Series and departed with a 2-1 lead in the eighth inning. Why so emotional?    The usually placid Key was emotional that night because he knew the inevitable was chasing him. The Blue Jays won Game 4 and then captured the Series in Atlanta in Game 6 as Key notched another victory, this time in relief. But Key enjoyed the thrill of Toronto's first World Series title for only a few weeks before he was searching for a new employer as a free agent. The Uniform Now Says Yanks    On the walk to the dugout eight months ago, Key probably sensed that he had pitched his final game in Toronto. Nine years of baseball memories in the same city were condensed into seconds. His eyes turned glassy. He has not returned there since.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Some Scientists, Less Money Is Just as Good
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the first time in modern memory, leaders in science have suggested that science does not need an increase in Federal funds to keep the United States ahead in the world's quest for knowledge. They even suggest that some fields might need to take less money to allow others to expand.   A committee of the National Academy of Sciences, the Institute of Medicine and the National Academy of Engineeringreleased a report today saying it is time for scientists to give ratings to the nation's progress in various fields of science, with an eye to determining just how much money society should spend on science, and in which fields.

nytimes_articles.headline: Study on Soviet-Era A-Plants Says Replacement Is Feasible
nytimes_articles.abstract: A confidential report on nuclear energy in the former Soviet bloc says it would be economically feasible to close 25 of the most dangerous nuclear reactors during the next few years and replace them with gas-fired power plants.   But the report says the former Communist countries oppose such a plan and want to keep their nuclear plants going as long as possible, a choice that could prove more dangerous and costlier for the West.

nytimes_articles.headline: Commuter Tax Is Left Intact By High Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York State's method of taxing nonresidents, which has prompted protests from commuters from neighboring states, was allowed to stand yesterday by the United States Supreme Court.    Hours after the Court declined to hear a challenge to New York's tax method, the New Jersey Senate approved a bill that would impose the same tax technique on workers who commute to jobs in that state from elsewhere. Some Senate members said that they were explicitly retaliating against New York.  [ Page B5. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: If He Runs, D'Amato Has His Platform
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that he would decide this fall whether to run for governor next year.   But he told a luncheon meeting here that if he were elected, he would sell the World Trade Center, the New York City airports and the state's Offtrack Betting system. He also said he would support the death penalty and require able-bodied welfare recipients to accept public-service jobs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Costly Learning Curves : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "The Cost Disease of Personal Services" (June 7): .Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan expands a small truth into a big lie in this opinion column. Yes, unit costs are unlikely to fall rapidly in sectors of the economy with slow product

nytimes_articles.headline: Intake Center For Homeless To Be Closed
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City's Human Resources Commissioner decided yesterday to close permanently a center in downtown Manhattan that places homeless people in shelters, three days after a caseworker was assaulted by a homeless woman there, administration officials said. But the move appeared to prompt a new crisis in the city's troublesome battle to shelter people who have nowhere to stay.   The center, at 78 Catherine Street, has been closed since Friday when staff members walked outafter the attack, saying that the center had become too dangerous and uncontrolled, in part because of over-crowding. With the Catherine Street center closed, the city started sending the families to another center in the Bronx, and last night about 100 families appeared at the door,, double the usual number. Yesterday's decision means that families will continue to be sent there, despite the overcrowded conditions.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: 10 More Quit Japan's Party   Members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party formed another new party, further weakening the Government of Kiichi Miyazawa. Page A6. Costly Delays on Health Care    Most economists agree that delaying curbs on escalating medical costs will be even more expensive than the Clinton health-care plan. Page D1. Easing Stand on Aid to Hanoi    Aides to President Clinton are urging him to end his opposition to plan to bring Vietnam back into the International Monetary Fund. Page A9. China's Controversial Dam    It will create a lake 350 miles long and save millions from flooding. Or it may simply create the world's largest mud pie. Science Times, page C1. Studio's Jitters Over 'Hero'    "Last Action Hero" took in a relatively low $15.3 million its first weekend, and Columbia Pictures executives are on the spot. Page C13.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tottenville Runner A True Iron Horse
nytimes_articles.abstract: Peter Westbrook, a five-time Olympic fencer, will be the guest speaker at the Public Schools Athletic League Iron Horse Awards dinner tonight at the Downtown Athletic Club.    Kevin Jermyn of Tottenville High School on Staten Island, the Iron Horse winner in all three track categories (indoor, outdoor and cross- country), will be among the 14 top senior male athletes in 16 sports at regular four-year schools honored.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rights Groups Fault Decision, As Do Haitians
nytimes_articles.abstract: Calling the ruling "shameful" and "abhorrent," human rights advocates and Haitians living here responded with consternation today to the Supreme Court's endorsement of the Clinton Administration's policy of forcing Haitian refugees intercepted in international waters to return to their homeland.   "This is a crime," said Max Pierre, an electronics engineer who came to Miami from Haiti as an illegal immigrant but is now an American citizen. "How can you send people back to a place where whole families are being killed and there is no justice? This goes against the democratic spirit of the American people."

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Early Autumn
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yesterday was the official start of summer. But for millions of Americans who shop by catalogue, there's already a nip of autumn in the mail.   Never mind the beach weather, the long hours of daylight or that the Fourth of July is still two weeks away. A number of leading mail-order companies have begun sending out the first of their fall catalogues.

nytimes_articles.headline: Excerpts From High Court Decision Upholding Policy on Haitian Refugees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding the Bush and Clinton Administrations' policy of intercepting Haitian refugees at sea and returning them to Haiti. The vote in Sale v. Haitian Centers Council was 8 to 1. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the majority opinion, and Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote the dissent. FROM THE DECISION By Justice Stevens    The President has directed the Coast Guard to intercept vessels illegally transporting passengers from Haiti to the United States and to return those passengers to Haiti without first determining whether they may qualify as refugees. The question presented in this case is whether such forced repatriation, "authorized to be undertaken only beyond the territorial sea of the United States," violates Sections 243(h)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 (I.N.A. or Act). We hold that neither Sections 243(h) nor Article 33 of the United Nations Protocol Relating to the Status of Refugees applies to action taken by the Coast Guard on the high seas.                    . . .         Aliens residing illegally in the United States are subject to deportation after a formal hearing. Aliens arriving at the border, or those who are temporarily paroled into the country, are subject to an exclusion hearing, the less formal process by which they, too, may eventually be removed from the United States. In either a deportation or exclusion proceeding the alien may seek asylum as a political refugee for whom removal to a particular country may threaten his life or freedom. Requests that the Attorney General grant asylum or withhold deportation to a particular country are typically, but not necessarily, advanced as parallel claims in either a deportation or an exclusion proceeding.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kate Reid Memorial
nytimes_articles.abstract: A memorial service for the actress Kate Reid is to be held next Tuesday at 11 A.M. at St. Clement's Church Theater, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton. It will include readings, performances and reminiscences about Ms. Reid, who died on March 27 at the age of 63.

nytimes_articles.headline: Agassi's Hopes Bloom On All England's Lawns
nytimes_articles.abstract: A perfect layer of grass awaited Andre Agassi at the All England Club with the serenity of a still lake at dawn. At least he beheld it this way, for as long as he could, until finally it was time for him to make a mess of it. .With his first shot it ch

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: American Composers Orchestra  Carnegie Hall    Bringing musical cultures together is a process much on the minds of classical music presenters. Wednesday's audience for a concert by the American Composers Orchestra -- many of its number were delegates at this week's American Symphony Orchestra League convention -- got a close look at one elegant and surprisingly simple way of reconciling the often irreconcilable.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Jurassic Park' Won't Turn Kids Against Science; Not That Spock
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Evil Science Runs Amok -- Again!" by Carol Muske Dukes (Op-Ed, June 10) decries the portrayal that science and its personnel have endured by the mass media.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton's Lost Half-Brother? To Neighbors, He's Just Leon
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sound of an incessantly ringing telephone inside Henry Leon Ritzenthaler's empty house pierced the afternoon stillness today in the piney woods here in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.    Mr. Ritzenthaler, known around here as Leon, says he is President Clinton's half-brother, and today he was on his way to New York City and the circuit of national television appearances that are the automatic badge of celebrity these days.

nytimes_articles.headline: New York City School Board Selects 10 Finalists in Search for Chancellor
nytimes_articles.abstract: The top 10 candidates to succeed New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez are the current school superintendents in Detroit, San Francisco, Washington and Fairfax County, Va.; two senior aides to Mr. Fernandez; New York's deputy education commissioner; Connecticut's former Education Commissioner; a foundation director, and the chief executive of a California software company.   The list of finalists, whose names were provided by several members of the New York City Board of Education, is made up of five blacks, three Hispanic people and two whites.

nytimes_articles.headline: CUNY Overhaul Assailed
nytimes_articles.abstract: A plan to overhaul academic programs throughout the City University of New York was denounced yesterday by dozens of faculty members, students, artists and intellectuals as an effort to destroy the university's attempts to provide a broad-based education for poor students. The criticism was made at a public hearing of the university's board at the Hunter College School of Social Work.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: BOXING  Griman Stops Ioka and Retains Title  David Griman of Venezuela stopped Hiroki Ioka of Japan at 2 minutes 38 seconds of the eighth round yesterday to retain his World Boxing Association flyweight title. Referee Manuel Rodriguez of Colombia stopped the scheduled 12-round bout, held in Osaka, Japan, when Griman forced Ioka to the ropes and punished him with a barrage of rights and lefts. Griman, 26, was making his first defense of the title that he won from fellow Venezuelan Aquiles Guzman. He improved to 18-1 with 11 knockouts. Ioka, 24, dropped to 22-4-1. Both fighters weighed the class limit of 112 pounds. (AP) SOCCER  U.S. Women Get an Indoor Victory  Joy Fawcett's two first-half goals propelled the United States' women's soccer team to a 3-0 victory over Canada last night on the new grass field in the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich. This was the first women's international soccer game played on an indoor grass field. The Silverdome is one of the venues for the 1994 World Cup, and the grass has been temporarily installed as a dry run for the Cup. The United States women, the defending world champions, have won six straight games and are 7-3 for 1993. It was their second victory over Canada in nine days, following a 7-0 rout in Cincinnati. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Make Room at Top: Janzen Doesn't Figure to Tail Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: For all the richness of the Baltusrol Golf Club's storied past, its seventh United States Open filled the golf horizon with thoughts of the future.   That was because the winner, Lee Janzen, showed the kind of poise, ability and mettle that seems built to last. Although there is nothing about his game or personality that is outwardly spectacular, the performance of the 28-year-old who makes his home in Kissimmee, Fla., left a strong impression that he is an Open champion who won't fade away.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: There's a new job -- and a new fashion scene -- for ANNIE FLANDERS, the founder and former editor of Details magazine. Ms. Flanders will be shaping coverage of California fashion and life style for Buzz magazine, a monthly publication about Los Angeles. She has been named consultant for a new section of the magazine, L.A. Style, itself formerly a magazine, which Buzz acquired from American Express.    "I want to pay attention to the fashion and garment business in Los Angeles, which doesn't have a high profile anywhere but is the second-largest business in L.A., larger even than show business," Ms. Flanders said yesterday from Shokan, N.Y., while traveling. (What's bigger? Aeronautics, she said).

nytimes_articles.headline: Nets Get Benjamin In Swap For Bowie
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Nets traded center Sam Bowie to the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday in exchange for 7-foot center Benoit Benjamin and a future second-round draft pick, the beginning of a number of personnel moves as the team adjusts to life without Drazen Petrovic and probably Chris Dudley. Petrovic, a guard, was killed in an automobile accident in Germany two weeks ago. Dudley, a backup center, is chasing big bucks in the free-agent market.   General Manager Willis Reed said that the trade was made as sort of a possible cushion in case Dudley, an unrestricted free agent who has drawn tremendous interest around the league, will not be back with New Jersey.

nytimes_articles.headline: 12 Indicted on Charges of Smuggling Aliens
nytimes_articles.abstract: The captain and the 10-member crew of the Golden Venture, the ship that ran aground off Queens two weeks ago with nearly 300 illegal Chinese immigrants aboard, were indicted yesterday on conspiracy and smuggling charges.   A 12th man who the authorities said acted as an enforcer for the organizers of the ill-fated voyage was also charged with trying to sneak the would-be immigrants into the United States, according to the indictment brought by Zachary W. Carter, United States Attorney in Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pope Endorses Bishops' Attempts To Rid Clergy of Child Molesters
nytimes_articles.abstract: In his first public statement on a problem that has shaken the Catholic Church in the United States, Pope John Paul II has told American bishops that he will help them use existing church law as far as possible to remove child molesters from the ranks of the priesthood.   In a letter released yesterday in Rome and Washington, the Pope told the bishops that he fully shared their sorrow and concern for the young victims "so seriously hurt by these misdeeds."  [ Excerpts, page A14. ]  And he said a committee of experts from the Vatican and the National Conference of Catholic Bishops would study how to apply church law, known as canon law, to the situation.  Shift in Attitudes    Six American cardinals recently traveled to Rome and asked the Pope directly for his help, several individuals familiar with the workings of the American church reported. The cardinals, they said, acted en masse after previous visits to Vatican officials by Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua of Philadelphia did not produce any sign that church law might be adjusted or streamlined so that American bishops could act more swiftly and decisively against molesting priests.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Politics of Meaning : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Kelly's articles on Hillary Rodham Clinton (May 25 and 26) and her "politics of meaning" missed the point. First, the evolution of Mrs. Clinton's political philosophy and the fact that she is a child of the liberal generation do not in

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; The Trade in Spies: Not All Black or White
nytimes_articles.abstract: Spy Trader  Germany's Devil's Advocate and the Darkest Secrets of the Cold War  By Craig R. Whitney  Illustrated. 375 pages. Times Books. $25.   The cold war gave the world not just heroes and villains, but also a gray supporting cast of spies, middlemen and mercenaries who lived and operated in the shadows. Of these, few are as intriguing as Wolfgang Vogel, the mysterious East German lawyer who, during the three decades the Berlin wall stood, quietly brokered the clandestine exchange of spies and the ransom of some 30,000 political prisoners from East Germany and the Soviet bloc. This unsavory business netted the Communists billions of dollars and made Mr. Vogel one of the richest and most influential private citizens behind what was once called the Iron Curtain.

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'L'Elisir d'Amore'  Metropolitan Opera in Prospect Park    Opera in the park is startling enough, but bel canto on a Brooklyn ball field: that's entertainment. "L'Elisir d'Amore" is one of two concert productions that the Met is taking to various parks around the New York area; Beautiful Prospect Park was the host on Wednesday night. The sun set over the darkening woods; candles glowed among picnic spreads; dogs pricked up their ears; policemen grumbled about missing the Suns-Bulls game; a nearby group of soccer-playing youths looked on in bewilderment ("What are they doing over there?"). Amid all this the first strains of Donizetti sounded a bit unreal, but the music seemed to stretch itself and fill the space.

nytimes_articles.headline: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Ervin Staub; Studying the Pivotal Role of Bystanders
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT was the summer of 1944, and 6-year-old Ervin Staub and his family, like other Jews in Budapest, were being set apart from their neighbors by laws imposed by the Nazis. Food was strictly rationed, and Ervin's 13-year-old cousin Eva, desperate to get a loaf of bread for her family, was waiting in a long bakery line after the curfew for Jews and without the yellow Star of David she was supposed to wear.   "Someone pointed her out as a Jew, and three young thugs tried to take her away," said Dr. Staub, now a psychologist at the University of Massachusetts, who vividly recalls the incident. "But she ran into our house to hide, and my aunt yelled at the thugs with such defiance that she scared them away."

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Looks to Conference Panel to Restore Budget to His Liking
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton and his top aides spent the day whipping up citizen support for his five-year, $500 billion budget package, but not entirely out of fear about its chances in the Senate.   To the contrary, Democrats are confident that the Senate will pass the plan after it is introduced on Wednesday.   They are less certain about their prospects in the legislative conference that follows, which promises to be a drawn-out effort to fuse the Senate's bill and the more liberal version that the House passed last month.

nytimes_articles.headline: 4th Endeavour Flight Pursues European Satellite
nytimes_articles.abstract: The space shuttle Endeavour and its crew of six bolted into the sky in a hail of fire and smoke today on a mission to retrieve an orbiting European science laboratory and to practice space-walking techniques.   After lifting off at 9:07 A.M., about 22 seconds late after an unidentified small aircraft appeared to intrude into restricted airspace near the Kennedy Space Center, the Endeavour pierced a cloud bank and began a three-day orbital chase to track and catch the satellite.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q&A
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Cooling Fan   Q.  Do fans actually make a room cooler?    A.  They can, but their main influence on rendering a stifling room bearable is probably on the individual perspiring body in the room, said Dr. David Goodstein, vice provost and professor of physics and applied physics at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, Calif.

nytimes_articles.headline: Political Memo; Shades of Perot: Parties Go For the Grass Roots
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sometimes loudly, sometimes quietly, Republicans and Democrats are grousing about Ross Perot at every turn. But they are not reluctant to imitate him.   Six months after Mr. Perot proclaimed the formation of his own grass-roots organization, the Republican Party announced today that it was doing the same thing, and that its group would use the same kind of public opinion surveys the Perot group does. Not to be left out, the Democratic Party is establishing its own group that may even have a toll-free telephone number, a la Perot.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trottier Leaving Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bryan Trottier's return to the Islanders as an executive appears to be over. The team has called a news conference today on Long Island and is expected to announce that Trottier will return to the Pittsburgh Penguins, this time possibly for a playing comeback or for a management position.   Trottier, who broke in with the Islanders in 1975, played 15 seasons in New York before joining the Penguins in 1991 for two more years. After announcing his retirment last summer, he rejoined the Islanders as a vice president.

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; It's A Pandemic
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. W.C.T. of Otisville, N.Y., has a grievance against "names." They don't answer his letters. He has sent me a letter complaining about it.   What Mr. W.C.T. means by "names" is that small group of Americans who do all the talking, or writing, or performing, or bossing. Then there are "ordinary" people, meaning people who get the epistolary cold shoulder from the "names." Or as Mr. W.C.T. puts it:

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. MAY LET HANOI GET I.M.F. FUNDING
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's senior foreign policy advisers have concluded that the Administration should no longer attempt to block loans to Hanoi from the International Monetary Fund, senior Administration officials said tonight. The recommendation could presage an easing of the relationship between the United States and Vietnam.   In a meeting last week, members of the National Security Council decided to recommend to the President that the United States raise no objections to a plan by France and Japan to pay more than $140 million in arrears that Hanoi owes to the fund. Such an action would free the monetary fund to approve new lending to Vietnam during its next board meeting in July.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  National League   CHICAGO CUBS -- Signed Gamalier Castro and Daniel Gil, pitchers; Brett McCabe and Kevin Orie, infielders; and Vee Hightower and John Sauer, outfielders. International Baseball Association   IBA CONGRESS -- Elected Aldo Notraui as president; Richard Case as secretary general; Mark Marquess to the technical commission; Neil Lantz to the legal commission; and Warren Turner to the youth commission.

nytimes_articles.headline: Empire Blue Cross Says It Paid Claims Without Checking Them
nytimes_articles.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield routinely paid claims from doctors, hospitals and pharmacies without any attempt to determine whether the claims had already been paid or might be fraudulent, company officials acknowledged yesterday.   The officials decided that it was cheaper simply to pay the claims than to program their computers to check them. A memorandum, prepared in February by the head of internal audits for Empire, made an urgent appeal to change and upgrade the computer system. Empire provided the memorandum yesterday in response to a request from The New York Times.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of a production error, an article about a renewal of fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina was omitted from some copies yesterday, and an outdated article, from the previous day, appeared under its headline.  Readers wishing copies of the correct article, carrying the dateline "June 20," may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; Lena Horne and the Stuff of Legend
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lena Horne gave a performance at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening that should become legend. She was the top-billed musician in the JVC Jazz Festival's tribute to Billy Strayhorn, and she reduced the audience to shivers with the story of how she met the composer and arranger who was Duke Ellington's musical right arm. Then, in rivetingly energized performances of several Strayhorn songs topped off with a fiery rendition of "Stormy Weather," she brought the audience to its feet. It was an accomplishment that few performers could have carried off at any age, let alone at 75.    Her first meeting with Strayhorn was in 1942 in California, she recalled. She was sitting in a theater feeling lonely when she was approached by "a beautiful brown boy in big horn-rimmed glasses, who looked like a lovely brown owl." He had been sent over by Ellington to see if she wanted something from the refreshment stand.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Jurassic Park' Won't Turn Kids Against Science
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I believe that "Evil Science Runs Amok -- Again!" by Carol Muske Dukes (Op-Ed, June 10) misses the point in arguing that from "Frankenstein" to "Jurassic Park" popular entertainments have made us fearful of science.

nytimes_articles.headline: Well, at Least He Didn't Spit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Knoxville Smokies Manager GARTH IORG and pitcher TRAVIS BAPTIST were ejected from a 3-2 Southern League loss to Chattanooga.   What was their sin? Did they curse the umpires? Kick dirt on the plate? Chase a heckler in the stands? None of the above.   Baptist was chewing tobacco in the dugout on Sunday. Iorg was chased for not stopping him.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; A Family Battles Incest's Taint, and the Dangers of a Lie
nytimes_articles.abstract: One for the My-How-Times-Change Department. Back in 1984, "Something About Amelia," a television movie starring Ted Danson and Glenn Close, created a stir and drew hefty ratings as it very carefully explored what was then the explosive subject of incest. Now, after Donahue, Oprah, Geraldo and other talk-show hosts have tramped through the same subject for years, incest is something of a television staple.    The latest example, a television-film import from Canada, can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 2. Written by Nancy Isaak and directed by Jorge Montesi, "Liar, Liar" begins as a portrait of the close-knit Farrow family whose only disruptive member appears to be an 11-year-old daughter named Kelley (Vanessa King). A spirited girl, she has a reputation for exaggerating and making up stories. Her dad, Gil (Art Hindle), an unemployed shipbuilder, swerves between disciplining Kelley harshly for various infractions and assuring her that she is, as his favorite song puts it, "my special angel."

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Jurassic Park' Won't Turn Kids Against Science; Biotechnology's Uses
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   You ask, "Should We Revive The Dinosaurs?" (editorial, June 13). Aw, I don't know. Maybe we can get those "arrogant, unscrupulous and unthinking scientists" that Steven Spielberg portrays so well in "Jurassic Park" to concentrate instead on unicorns or pigs with wings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Filadelfia Journal; The Godly Make Paraguay's 'Green Hell' Bloom
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a seasonal water hole north of here, a cowboy recently came across a stand of ancient bottle trees, so called because their pear-shaped trunks were believed to contain water.   In the shade of the thorn-covered trees, he found rotting cartridge belts and rusting canteens, reminders of 5,000 Bolivian soldiers who gathered at the water hole, only to die of thirst.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trenton Authorizes a $15.4 Billion Spending Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Legislature today passed a $15.4 billion budget for fiscal year 1994 that includes a $150 million reserve fund that has become the focal point of election year debate.   The budget also includes $25 million in anticipated revenue from a retaliatory commuter tax on New Yorkers, which a decision today by the United States Supreme Court guaranteed can be legally collected.

nytimes_articles.headline: Turning to the Garden, Rural India Heals Itself
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tulasia Row is very ill. The one-year-old, his emaciated body resting in his mother's arms, is in danger of succumbing to the biggest killer of Indian infants, diarrhea. Then Vijaya Kumari - a local representative of ASHA, a private voluntary group that

nytimes_articles.headline: Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sixty years ago an aggressive player like the world champion, Alexander Alekhine, steered away from symmetrical positions because he believed they were conducive to draws. If the opponent has everything I have, how can I claim to have any advantage and justify playing to win? But nowadays there are ways to combat the sterility of symmetry.   For one thing, today's players are ingenious in finding moves that cannot be copied and, in fact, few games continue for very long if Black can maintain an arid balance of position. White's advantage of moving first is the key to avoiding symmetry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Let Sleeping Subs Lie
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Apathy Above, Terror Below" by Igor Spassky (Op-Ed, June 3) is sensationalizing and wrong to argue for raising the submarine Komsomolets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Birds With Attitude
nytimes_articles.abstract: They first noticed something amiss when a bird whizzed by their heads about three weeks ago, so close it nearly touched them. Now every time they venture onto their Manhattan rooftop, they're dive-bombed. It's gotten so bad that when a neighbor goes out onto his terrace one floor below, he's attacked too.   The birds are aggressively defending their space, not to mention the next generation. They've built a nest, and turned the rooftop into forbidden territory, making it impossible to tend the plants, pick the few struggling roses, enjoy the water-tower view. They've even intimidated the cat, an old, deaf calico that just wants to stretch in the sun.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rostropovich and Johns Win Awards
nytimes_articles.abstract: The painter Jasper Johns and the cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich are among the five winners of the 1993 Japanese Praemium Imperiale awards for lifetime achievement in the arts. The prize winners were announced yesterday in Berlin by Helmut Schmidt, the former West German Chancellor.   Each winner is to receive $138,000. The others named are the French choreographer Maurice Bejart, the Swiss sculptor Max Bill and the Japanese architect Kenzo Tange.

nytimes_articles.headline: Columbia Ponders The Fate Of 'Hero'
nytimes_articles.abstract: A producer at Columbia Pictures didn't show up for work today because, he said, the atmosphere was just too poisonous. At breakfast this morning at a Beverly Hills hotel, an agent glanced down at her shredded wheat and whispered, "There are a lot of depressed people at Columbia." By lunch time, the questions all over town were: Who's to blame? Who's the fall guy?   Although it's far too early to call "Last Action Hero" a flop, Columbia's super-hyped, super-expensive Arnold Schwarzenegger adventure fantasy seemed, to most Hollywood executives, the summer's financial disappointment, grossing only $15.3 million in its first weekend. In contrast, Steven Spielberg's dinosaur adventure, "Jurassic Park," grossed a record $50.1 million in its first weekend and $38.5 million this past weekend, its second.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; 'Camelot' Returns With Goulet as King
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the first Broadway musical by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe after "My Fair Lady," "Camelot" was as highly anticipated as a coronation. At the time, the advance sale was the largest in Broadway history. The 1960 musical, which turned out to be the last Lerner and Loewe theatrical collaboration, has grown in stature over the years, primarily because of its superb score.    Drawing upon themes from T. H. White's "Once and Future King," the score combined a lyrical simplicity with a lush romanticism, beautifully captured in numbers like "I Loved You Once in Silence" and "If Ever I Would Leave You." These ballads sung by Guenevere and Lancelot are among the most memorable in the Lerner-Loewe catalogue. King Arthur supplies the wit, with songs like "I Wonder What the King Is Doing Tonight." Subsequently, the title song joined Arthurian legend with American political mythology.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: There is some pretty impressive artwork hanging on the walls in United States embassies abroad, and now in the residence of MADELEINE K. ALBRIGHT, American delegate to the United Nations, at the Waldorf Towers as well.   Tonight she's giving a party at her official residence there to celebrate the Friends of Art and Preservation in Embassies foundation and the 21 artists whose works have been donated to a new collection for her walls. They include Willem De Kooning, Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Roy Lichtenstein, Claes Oldenburg and Frank Stella.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patriots' Running Back Out of Hospital
nytimes_articles.abstract: New England Patriots running back LEONARD RUSSELL was released from Massachusetts General Hospital, three days after he was hospitalized with stab wounds in the chest.   Russell, 23, was stabbed early Friday after getting into an argument outside a nightclub. The police said yesterday they have identified a suspect but still haven't made any arrests.

nytimes_articles.headline: State Is Seeking to Disband Town's Private Police Force
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Jersey state lawyers plan to go to court on Tuesday to try to force tiny Sussex Borough to disband its uniformed security force, which looks like a regular police department but, by law, cannot function like one.   Robert T. Winter, the director of the State Division of Criminal Justice, said the municipality's security guards have no more enforcement powers than "everyday citizens" and could pose a danger to themselves or the public if they try to act as police officers.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-13  BOSNIAN REPLACED IN TALKS  President Alija Izetbegovic was replaced as head of Bosnia's delegation on the eve of key peace talks opening in Geneva with Serbian and Croatian leaders on their plan to divide the country into three loosely confederated ethnic states.  A1  KOHL BACKS ARMS FOR BOSNIA  Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany surprised and irritated his European Community partners by pressing strongly for an end to the arms embargo on Bosnian Muslims at a regional summit meeting that ended in Copenhagen.  A6

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
